p: The different GHG-generating models mentioned above also define access to material and social resources, which have a direct effect on health. These include employment and working conditions, housework and caregiving, income and the economic situation, housing and the material situation, the residential environment, social capital, social support, and social networks, as well as education. Unequal access to these material and social resources along different axes of inequality, together with lack of power, are the main causes of existing health inequalities [28,29]. At the same time, this unequal access modulates exposure to the effects of climate change and adaptive capacity, thus exacerbating social inequalities in health.
